name: Kepler-200
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-200 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-200 is a star with 0.857 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.94 times its radius. It is located 2214.37 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-200 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-200 b

Kepler-200 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 8.59 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-200.

The mass of Kepler-200 b is 5.90 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-200 b is 2.13 that of Earth. At 5.90 Earth masses, Kepler-200 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-200 c

Kepler-200 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 10.22 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-200.

The mass of Kepler-200 c is 2.94 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-200 c is 1.59 that of Earth. At 2.94 Earth masses, Kepler-200 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-200, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
